question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Compute
\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^{2016}.\]
inference:
We can compute the first few powers of the matrix:
\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & -8 \\ 2 & -3 \end{pmatrix},\]\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^3 = \begin{pmatrix} 7 & -12 \\ 3 & -5 \end{pmatrix},\]\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^4 = \begin{pmatrix} 9 & -16 \\ 4 & -7 \end{pmatrix}.\]We see a pattern:
\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^n = \begin{pmatrix} 2n + 1 & -4n \\ n & -2n + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]We can prove this by induction.  The base case $n = 1$ is clear.  Assume that the formula holds for some positive integer $n.$  Then
\begin{align*}
\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^{n + 1} &= \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^n \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 2n + 1 & -4n \\ n & -2n + 1 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 2n + 3 & -4n - 4 \\ n + 1 & -2n - 1 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 2(n + 1) + 1 & -4(n + 1) \\ n + 1 & -2(n + 1) + 1 \end{pmatrix},
\end{align*}so the formula holds for $n + 1.$

Therefore,
\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^{2016} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4033 & -8064 \\ 2016 & -4031 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
ground_truth:
Let $\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}.$  Note that
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{A}^2 &= \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 5 & -8 \\ 2 & -3 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= 2 \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} -  \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= 2 \mathbf{A} - \mathbf{I}.
\end{align*}Thus, let
\[\mathbf{B} = \mathbf{A} - \mathbf{I} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -4 \\ 1 & -2 \end{pmatrix}.\]Then $\mathbf{B}^2 = \mathbf{0},$ and $\mathbf{A} = \mathbf{B} + \mathbf{I},$ so by the Binomial Theorem,
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{A}^{2016} &= (\mathbf{B} + \mathbf{I})^{2016} \\
&= \mathbf{B}^{2016} + \binom{2016}{1} \mathbf{B}^{2015} + \binom{2016}{2} \mathbf{B}^{2014} + \dots + \binom{2016}{2014} \mathbf{B}^2 + \binom{2016}{2015} \mathbf{B} + \mathbf{I} \\
&= 2016 \mathbf{B} + \mathbf{I} \\
&= 2016 \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -4 \\ 1 & -2 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4033 & -8064 \\ 2016 & -4031 \end{pmatrix}}.
\end{align*}Note: We can expand $(\mathbf{B} + \mathbf{I})^{2016}$ using the Binomial Theorem because the matrices $\mathbf{B}$ and $\mathbf{I}$ commute, i.e. $\mathbf{B} \mathbf{I} = \mathbf{I} \mathbf{B}.$  In general, expanding a power of $\mathbf{A} + \mathbf{B}$ is difficult.  For example,
\[(\mathbf{A} + \mathbf{B})^2 = \mathbf{A}^2 + \mathbf{A} \mathbf{B} + \mathbf{B} \mathbf{A} + \mathbf{B}^2,\]and without knowing more about $\mathbf{A}$ and $\mathbf{B},$ this cannot be simplified.

question:
We can compute the first few powers of the matrix:
\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & -8 \\ 2 & -3 \end{pmatrix},\]\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^3 = \begin{pmatrix} 7 & -12 \\ 3 & -5 \end{pmatrix},\]\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^4 = \begin{pmatrix} 9 & -16 \\ 4 & -7 \end{pmatrix}.\]We see a pattern:
\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^n = \begin{pmatrix} 2n + 1 & -4n \\ n & -2n + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]We can prove this by induction.  The base case $n = 1$ is clear.  Assume that the formula holds for some positive integer $n.$  Then
\begin{align*}
\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^{n + 1} &= \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^n \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 2n + 1 & -4n \\ n & -2n + 1 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 2n + 3 & -4n - 4 \\ n + 1 & -2n - 1 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 2(n + 1) + 1 & -4(n + 1) \\ n + 1 & -2(n + 1) + 1 \end{pmatrix},
\end{align*}so the formula holds for $n + 1.$

Therefore,
\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^{2016} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4033 & -8064 \\ 2016 & -4031 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
There might be an error in the solution above because of lack of understanding of the question. Please correct the error, if any, and rewrite the solution. Only output the final solution \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
inference:
The solution is correct.  There is no error.
